titleStmt.title: Approved, good, and happy newes from Ireland: relating how the castle of Artaine was taken from the rebels, two of their captaines kild, and one taken prisoners by the protestants. With the arrivall of 2000 foot, and 300 horse from England. Also a great skirmish betweene the Protestants and the rebels at a place neere Feleston, wherein the English obtained great renowne and victory. Whereunto is added, a true relation of the great overthrow which the English gave the rebels before Drogheda sent in a letter bearing date the 27 of February. to Sir Robert King Knight at Cecill house in the Strand. Printed by order of Parliament.
titleStmt.author: Loftus, Edward, 17th cent.

fileDesc.extent: Approx. 10 KB of XML-encoded text transcribed from 5 1-bit group-IV TIFF page images.

This waiver does not extend to any page images or other supplementary files associated with this work, which may be protected by copyright or other license restrictions. Please go to https://www.textcreationpartnership.org/ for more information about the project.

titleStmt.title: Approved, good, and happy newes from Ireland: relating how the castle of Artaine was taken from the rebels, two of their captaines kild, and one taken prisoners by the protestants. With the arrivall of 2000 foot, and 300 horse from England. Also a great skirmish betweene the Protestants and the rebels at a place neere Feleston, wherein the English obtained great renowne and victory. Whereunto is added, a true relation of the great overthrow which the English gave the rebels before Drogheda sent in a letter bearing date the 27 of February. to Sir Robert King Knight at Cecill house in the Strand. Printed by order of Parliament.

Reproduction of the original in the British Library.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

keywords.term: Ireland -- History -- Rebellion of 1641 -- Early works to 1800.

div.p: Approved, Good, and happy Newes From IRELAND:
Relating how the Ca≈øtle of Artaine was taken from the Rebels, two of their Captaines kild, and one taken pri≈øoners by the prote≈øtants.
With the arrivall of 2000 foot, and 300 hor≈øe from England.
Al≈øo a great skirmi≈øh betweene the Prote≈øtants and the Rebels at a place neere Fele≈øton, wherein the Engli≈øh obta ‚Ä¢ ned great renow ‚Ä¢ e and victory.

Whereunto is added, A true relation of the great overthrow which the Engli≈øh gave the Rebels before Drogheda ≈øent in a Letter bearing date the 27 of February. to Sir Robert King Knight at Cecill hou≈øe in the Strand.
Printed by Order of Parliament.
LONDON, Printed for Iohn Wright, 1641.

div.head: The la≈øt newes from IRELAND, 7 March, 1641.
div.p: THe 10. of February our men went to Artain, again≈øt a ca≈øtle ≈øo called, which had before done ≈øome mi≈øchiefe, to ≈øome of our men, the enemy being in it, But the enemy fled before our ≈øecond comming, and left the Ca≈øtle; and a garri≈øon was left in it by us.

Upon the 11th. wee had newes, that the enemy was intrenching at a place called Soughing Towne, ≈øome 6. Miles ≈øouth of our City, and ≈øome 2000. Foot, and 200. Hor≈øe went out again≈øt them; The Lord Lambart commanding in chiefe; A ≈ømall battell they had, but the Enemy ≈øtood not, on the Enemies ≈øide ≈øome 70 or more was killed, and but one hurt on our ≈øide, and ≈øo came home that night, and brought home one of the Rebells Captaines and two more of the enemies Captaines ≈ølaine, many Letters of trea≈øon were found about him that was taken.

On the 13. a man was brought to our City being taken by ≈øome of our ≈øcattering men ≈øcouting about our City, who confe≈øt without con≈øtraint, that he had killed an Engli≈øhwoman at a place called Le≈ølipe≈øom, 6. Miles We≈øt of our City, and wa≈øhed his hands in her bloud, being ≈øet on by the popi≈øh Prie≈øts ≈øo to doe, hee was pre≈øently hanged, but dyed with much repentance and a prote≈øtant, which few do.
Upon the 19. and 20. Arrived heere from you 2000 Foot and 300 hor≈øe but little or no money, which made us poore of the City fare harder then before; which was to hard.

Upon the 21. Wee had knowledge that our Ships ≈øent with vittaile to relieve Tredath had got ≈øafely in, and in ≈øpight of the enemy, who had chayned up the harbour, but our men brake the Chaine, and got in, notwith≈øtanding. And publike thankes was with us for that happine≈ø≈øe, for in ≈øuch a great ≈øtrait was that City, as to eat Hor≈øe fle≈øh, as letters from my friends from the City to mee te≈øtified; Al≈øo Captaine Bartlet who was the Sea Captaine, in his comming home met with ≈øome fore ≈ømall Boats or Barkes of the Wexford men, going toward the enemy in the North to carry Lenten provi≈øion, but hee ≈øpoyled their de≈øigne in ≈øinking mo≈øt or all of them, About the ≈øame time we had al≈øo Letters out of Mun≈øter, that all that part of the Countrey was ro≈øe in Rebellion being carried out by the Lord Mu≈øcry, and Lord Roch, who had profe≈ø≈øed much fidellity, and many deceitfull promi≈øes had pa≈øt to the pre≈øident of that Province, till they ≈øaw their owne advantage, And it is reported they are not le≈ø≈øe then 20000 ≈øtrong, be≈øt appointed of all the Rebels, for indeed this Lord Mu≈øcry is the mo≈øt monied man, of all the Iri≈øh Lords, So that now not one place in Ireland, but is in Rebellion, for the Lord of Clanrickard, ≈øtands as ≈øome thinke Neuter, does nothing at all, or cannot do any thing, or will not, But wee heare that our Pre≈øident of Mun≈øter was forced to betake him≈øelfe to the ≈øtrong hold of Corke, and the Lord of Corke betooke him≈øelfe to Yoyhall, which are
reported both to be be≈øiged by the enemy.

Upon the 23. of this moneth, newes was that at a place neere Fele≈øton ≈øix miles from us, a great multitude of the enemies had ≈øtrongly fortifide them≈øelves, and it is well fortifide by nature, having al≈øo a ≈øtrong Ca≈øtle in it; Some 3000 of our men went again≈øt it, hor≈øe and foote, Our Lord generall the Earle of Ormond him≈øelfe went, as did Sir Charles Coot, Sir Symond Ha ‚Ä¢ court, and many more, Iohn Moore being one of the Soldiers, and upon the forelorne hope. had both his left and right hand man killed, he told me that our generall him≈øelfe, led up the forlorne hope, with many words of Comfort to them, able to make any man fight to ≈øee ≈øuch a man as he goe in ≈øuch danger: For the enemy had a great wood to ≈øhelter them be≈øide trenches, but our men after 2 houres Battell, beat them from their Trench, and from the wood, killing ≈øome 80 of them, For all that advantage but 7 of our men was killed, but that we lo≈øt one Captaine Rochford, a man of ≈øuch note, that never more was any man bewayled; For all the good and valliant parts of a Soldier was in him, in this bout Sir Symond Harcourts Regiment, behaved them≈øelves valliantly but for the Ca≈øtle our men were forced to returne home without taking it, having nothing but field peeces with them, the way being to rotten to beare greater as yet; many more of the enemies had bin ≈ølaine but that the wood defended them, ≈øo that the Trees tooke off all that was ≈øent to them in this Ca≈øtle is thought to be much wealth be≈øides all that have bin great men of the Rebels. But our men will not ≈øo leave it, but will againe try their forces again≈øt it ≈øhortly.

As ye≈øterday our men came home, yet tis to be feard that a famine is like to be in our City, in that ≈øtill men come to us and provi≈øion is ≈øhort, and none of yours that come to us bring any vittailes, great taxes are upon us, more then can be borne, He that had Butter, and Chee≈øe, and Cloath at between 6 and 14 Shillings a yard here ≈øent by any out of London,, might make a good trade of it; Che≈øhire chee≈øe is ≈øould here for ≈øix pence a pound already; Some of your Londoners are come hither (acquaintance of mine) that will ≈øend for ≈øuch things, for great profit may be made by them, and quicke returne.

div.head: A letter ≈øent from Droheda, to Sir Robert King, dated Febr. 27.
div.p:
IN my la≈øt Letter, I ≈øignified to you the difficulties which were like to befall us by the releeving of Droheda, but God by his infinite mercy hath freed us (I may ≈øay miraculou≈øly) from that hazzard: for when our men there were driven to that extremity to eat hor≈øe-fle≈øh, Sir Henry Tichbourne ≈øallied out of the Towne with only fourty Musketiers, and fourty Hor≈øe, and beat off foure hundred of the enemies, killed above three≈øcore of them, recovered four≈øcore Cowes and Oxen, and two hundred Sheep; burned foure Townes, and brought
home two of their Colours: Be≈øides, I mu≈øt relate unto you Gods aboundant goodne≈ø≈øe unto us, in that the night before the reliefe and ≈øuccours which we ≈øent by Sea from Dublin to them, ≈øhould have entred into the Harbour of Droheda, which was ≈øtrongly fenced over with a Chaine and ≈øeverall boates, there happened a ≈øtorm which broke their chainer, and gave our men ≈øo great a pa≈ø≈øage, as with little difficulty they came ≈øafely to the Towne. The Rebels were gathered at Kil≈øhalgham within ≈øeven miles of Dublin, above two thou≈øand men, where they were ≈øetled in a very ≈øtrong wood. My Lord of Ormond carried out part of our Army, and beat them out of that great ≈øtrength (for they would not come into the Champaine) and killed above a hundred of them, without any con≈øiderable lo≈ø≈øe of our ≈øide, only Captaine Iames Rochfort, a mo≈øt gallant and couragious Gentleman. This was an act of great bravery, wherein Sir Charles Coote did, (as he doth alwaies) beyond expectation, expo≈øing his per≈øon to as much danger as any man living could; and in truth he is a gallant man, full of courage and good affections, and de≈øerves great encouragement from that ≈øide. Our ≈øouldiours are in great want of money, which cau≈øes a generall want of all other nece≈ø≈øaries, yet notwith≈øtanding God hath infu≈øed ≈øuch courage into them (for undoubtedly it is his worke) that they thinke there is no danger ≈øo great, but they may attempt it.

Colonell Munke is arrived here with my Lord Lieutenants Regiment of fifteen hundred foot, and Sir Richard Greevill with neere foure hundred Hor≈øe, which puts much heart into us, and makes us looke
big upon our neighbours, yet we grieve we cannot be able to releeve our friends in other parts, but I hope when our full ≈øuccours ≈øhall come, we ≈øhall not only defend this place, but adde comfort to our poore di≈øtre≈ø≈øed friends abroad.
The enemy though their numbers be very great, even beyond beliefe, yet their hearts begin to faint and I believe they repent their furious madne≈ø≈øe.

If my brother be in London, I pray you impart this Letter to him, I would hae written to him, but that I thought he was at Che≈øter, or on his way thither: By the next he ≈øhall heare from me at large, and I ≈øhall likewi≈øe trouble you.
I mu≈øt now only tell you, that I thank you for your care of tho≈øe things which concerne me, and I am, Sir,
'Tis this day Ordered forthwith, that this Letter be publi≈øhed in print.

closer.signed: H. El≈øing. Cler. P. D. Com.
